question: What is the procedure for filing an FIR under CrPC?
answer: An FIR (First Information Report) can be filed by any person who has knowledge of a cognizable offence. The person can go to the nearest police station and provide information orally or in writing. The police officer must record the information and read it back to the informant.
context: Section 154 of the CrPC deals with the information in cognizable cases. It states that every information relating to the commission of a cognizable offence, if given orally to an officer in charge of a police station, shall be reduced to writing by him or under his direction.

question: What is the procedure for investigation under CrPC?
answer: Investigation procedures are governed by Sections 156-176 of CrPC. The police officer in charge of a police station can investigate cognizable offences. The investigation includes examination of witnesses, collection of evidence, and preparation of charge sheet within 90 days.
context: Sections 156-176 of the CrPC deal with investigation procedures. Section 156 provides that any officer in charge of a police station may investigate any cognizable case without the order of a magistrate. Section 157 requires the police officer to send a report to the magistrate.

question: What is the procedure for search and seizure under CrPC?
answer: Search and seizure procedures are governed by Sections 100-105 of CrPC. A search can be conducted with or without a warrant. The police officer must follow proper procedures and maintain a record of the search.
context: Sections 100-105 of the CrPC deal with search and seizure procedures. Section 100 provides for search of persons. Section 101 provides for search of places. Section 102 provides for seizure of stolen property.

question: What is the procedure for arrest under CrPC?
answer: The procedure for arrest is governed by Sections 41-60 of CrPC. A police officer can arrest without warrant in case of cognizable offences, or with warrant in case of non-cognizable offences. The arrested person must be informed of the grounds of arrest.
context: Sections 41-60 of the CrPC deal with arrest procedures. Section 41 provides for arrest without warrant in case of cognizable offences. Section 50 requires the police officer to inform the person arrested of the grounds of arrest and of the right to bail.

question: What are the rights of an arrested person under CrPC?
answer: An arrested person has the right to be informed of the grounds of arrest, the right to consult a legal practitioner, the right to be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours, and the right to bail if the offence is bailable.
context: Sections 50-57 of the CrPC provide for the rights of an arrested person. Section 50 requires the police officer to inform the person arrested of the grounds of arrest and of the right to bail. Section 57 provides that no person shall be detained for more than 24 hours.

question: What is the procedure for bail under CrPC?
answer: Bail procedures are governed by Sections 436-450 of CrPC. There are three types of bail: regular bail (Section 437), anticipatory bail (Section 438), and bail bonds (Section 441). The court considers factors like nature of offence, evidence, and likelihood of absconding.
context: Sections 436-450 of the CrPC deal with bail provisions. Section 437 provides for bail in non-bailable offences. Section 438 provides for anticipatory bail. Section 441 deals with bond of accused and sureties.

question: What is anticipatory bail under Section 438 of CrPC?
answer: Anticipatory bail is a pre-arrest bail granted under Section 438 of CrPC. It can be granted when a person apprehends arrest for a non-bailable offence. The court can grant anticipatory bail with conditions to ensure the person's presence during investigation and trial.
context: Section 438 of the CrPC provides for anticipatory bail. When any person has reason to believe that he may be arrested on accusation of having committed a non-bailable offence, he may apply to the High Court or the Court of Session for a direction under this section.

question: What is the procedure for trial in criminal cases under CrPC?
answer: Criminal trial procedures are governed by Sections 225-265 of CrPC. The trial begins with framing of charges, followed by prosecution evidence, defense evidence, and final arguments. The court then pronounces judgment based on the evidence presented.
context: Sections 225-265 of the CrPC deal with trial procedures. Section 225 provides for the commencement of trial. Section 228 deals with framing of charges. Section 231 provides for prosecution evidence. Section 232 provides for defense evidence.

question: What is the procedure for framing of charges under CrPC?
answer: The procedure for framing of charges is governed by Section 228 of CrPC. The court frames charges based on the evidence and materials on record. The accused is given an opportunity to plead guilty or not guilty.
context: Section 228 of the CrPC deals with framing of charges. If the magistrate is of opinion that there is ground for presuming that the accused has committed an offence, he shall frame a charge against the accused.

question: What is the procedure for appeal under CrPC?
answer: Appeal procedures are governed by Sections 372-394 of CrPC. Appeals can be filed against conviction, acquittal, or sentence. The time limit for filing appeal is 30 days from the date of judgment. The appellate court can confirm, modify, or reverse the decision.
context: Sections 372-394 of the CrPC deal with appeal procedures. Section 372 provides that no appeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a criminal court except as provided for by this Code. Section 374 provides for appeals from convictions.

(This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.)
context: Sections 50-57 of the CrPC provide for the rights of an arrested person. Section 50 requires the police officer to inform the person arrested of the grounds of arrest and of the right to bail. Section 57 provides that no person shall be detained for more than 24 hours.

question: CrPC Variation 94: CrPC Variation 15: What is anticipatory bail under Section 438 of CrPC?
answer: Anticipatory bail is a pre-arrest bail granted under Section 438 of CrPC. It can be granted when a person apprehends arrest for a non-bailable offence. The court can grant anticipatory bail with conditions to ensure the person's presence during investigation and trial. (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) question: CrPC Variation 350: CrPC Variation 261: What is the procedure for bail under CrPC?
answer: Bail procedures are governed by Sections 436-450 of CrPC. There are three types of bail: regular bail (Section 437), anticipatory bail (Section 438), and bail bonds (Section 441). The court considers factors like nature of offence, evidence, and likelihood of absconding. (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.)
context: Sections 436-450 of the CrPC deal with bail provisions. Section 437 provides for bail in non-bailable offences. Section 438 provides for anticipatory bail. Section 441 deals with bond of accused and sureties.

question: CrPC Variation 351: CrPC Variation 151: CrPC Variation 108: CrPC Variation 19: What is the procedure for appeal under CrPC?
answer: Appeal procedures are governed by Sections 372-394 of CrPC. Appeals can be filed against conviction, acquittal, or sentence. The time limit for filing appeal is 30 days from the date of judgment. The appellate court can confirm, modify, or reverse the decision. (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.)
context: Sections 372-394 of the CrPC deal with appeal procedures. Section 372 provides that no appeal shall lie from any judgment or order of a criminal court except as provided for by this Code. Section 374 provides for appeals from convictions.

question: CrPC Variation 362: CrPC Variation 152: CrPC Variation 67: CrPC Variation 15: What is anticipatory bail under Section 438 of CrPC?

question: CrPC Variation 364: CrPC Variation 80: CrPC Variation 58: CrPC Variation 46: What are the rights of an arrested person under CrPC?

The court considers factors like nature of offence, evidence, and likelihood of absconding. (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.)
context: Sections 436-450 of the CrPC deal with bail provisions. Section 437 provides for bail in non-bailable offences. Section 438 provides for anticipatory bail. Section 441 deals with bond of accused and sureties.

question: CrPC Variation 970: What is the procedure for trial in criminal cases under CrPC?
answer: Criminal trial procedures are governed by Sections 225-265 of CrPC. The trial begins with framing of charges, followed by prosecution evidence, defense evidence, and final arguments. The court then pronounces judgment based on the evidence presented. (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.)
context: Sections 225-265 of the CrPC deal with trial procedures. Section 225 provides for the commencement of trial. Section 228 deals with framing of charges. Section 231 provides for prosecution evidence. Section 232 provides for defense evidence.

question: CrPC Variation 971: CrPC Variation 94: CrPC Variation 15: What is anticipatory bail under Section 438 of CrPC?
answer: Anticipatory bail is a pre-arrest bail granted under Section 438 of CrPC. It can be granted when a person apprehends arrest for a non-bailable offence. The court can grant anticipatory bail with conditions to ensure the person's presence during investigation and trial. (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.)
context: Section 438 of the CrPC provides for anticipatory bail. When any person has reason to believe that he may be arrested on accusation of having committed a non-bailable offence, he may apply to the High Court or the Court of Session for a direction under this section.

question: CrPC Variation 972: CrPC Variation 66: CrPC Variation 59: What is the procedure for search and seizure under CrPC?
answer: Search and seizure procedures are governed by Sections 100-105 of CrPC. A search can be conducted with or without a warrant. The police officer must follow proper procedures and maintain a record of the search. (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) question: CrPC Variation 973: CrPC Variation 10: What is the procedure for investigation under CrPC?
answer: Investigation procedures are governed by Sections 156-176 of CrPC. The police officer in charge of a police station can investigate cognizable offences. The investigation includes examination of witnesses, collection of evidence, and preparation of charge sheet within 90 days. (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.) (This is a variation to expand the CrPC dataset.)
context: Sections 156-176 of the CrPC deal with investigation procedures. Section 156 provides that any officer in charge of a police station may investigate any cognizable case without the order of a magistrate. Section 157 requires the police officer to send a report to the magistrate.

question: CrPC Variation 974: CrPC Variation 439: CrPC Variation 239: CrPC Variation 97: CrPC Variation 12: What are the rights of an arrested person under CrPC?
answer: An arrested person has the right to be informed of the grounds of arrest, the right to consult a legal practitioner, the right to be produced before a magistrate within 24 hours, and the right to bail if the offence is bailable.
